awd_abstract_narration:
Many activities of modern society and government depend on use of the electromagnetic (radio-frequency) spectrum. Future growth in these activities requires increased use of dynamic spectrum sharing – ways to enable diverse spectrum users to safely operate closer together in space or frequency or to trade spectrum access more rapidly than is possible with traditional spectrum management approaches. The National Science Foundation National Radio Dynamic Zones (SII-NRDZ) program seeks to advance the use of dynamic spectrum sharing through conducting extended field trials of new sharing approaches. The SII-NRDZ program intends to make a future award called the Engineering and Execution Lead (SII-NRDZ-EEL). The SII-NRDZ-EEL will provide the professional engineering and management required for success of SII-NRDZ program field trials.  In this project, the MITRE corporation conducts the initial planning, technical study, regulatory study, and program and outreach interactions needed to prepare a high-quality proposal to serve as the SII-NRDZ-EEL.

If selected as the SII-NRDZ-EEL, the MITRE Corporation envisions building infrastructure as a service that will accelerate the pace of research and field trials in spectrum sharing. This infrastructure is called “NRDZ-as-a-Service” (NaaS). NaaS will serve as the platform for maturing spectrum-sharing researchers’ solutions, for transitioning implementations from laboratory testing to large-scale field trials, and for rapidly conducting repeatable experiments at multiple field trial sites. NaaS will provide researchers the capability to construct custom dynamic spectrum sharing approaches that interact with spectrum users through standard interfaces. In the technical study portion of this project, MITRE performs initial design of NaaS services and interfaces, prototypes a representative NaaS to demonstrate its capability, and investigates architectural questions relevant for future spectrum sharing deployments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Spectrum Innovation Initiative: National Radio Dynamic Zones (SII-NRDZ) MITRE NRDZ-as-a-Service, led by The MITRE Corporation as the SII-NRDZ Engineering and Execution Lead (SII-NRDZ-EEL), has successfully performed technical investigations to be the operational lead for design, execution, and analysis of SII-NRDZ field trials. As the demand for spectrum continues to grow, our project aimed to develop innovative solutions to enable dynamic spectrum sharing through reliable field experimentation. This report highlights the key outcomes and impacts of our research, emphasizing its intellectual merit and broader societal impacts.

The cornerstone of the SII-NRDZ-EEL project was the development of NRDZ-as-a-Service (NaaS) concept, a pioneering infrastructure designed to facilitate dynamic spectrum sharing. This platform provided a transparent and insightful framework for stakeholders, including incumbents, new entrants, policymakers, and regulators, to confidently engage with spectrum sharing solutions. By leveraging MITRE's expertise in electronic systems, network technology, and systems integration, NaaS will enable researchers to transition their solutions from laboratory settings to large-scale field trials. The three core services provided by NaaS will include protecting spectrum incumbents and experimental performers from interference, creating NRDZ experiments through plug-n-play hardware/software toolkit components, and providing NaaS applications to assess and independently evaluate spectrum science research. Key technologies and concepts contributing to scientific advancement in spectrum science include radio frequency (RF) interference physics, situational awareness, and interference suppression. The NaaS framework will enable spectrum experiments through common interfaces and services for dynamic spectrum functions.

The project investigation emphasized the importance of long-duration field trials to support real spectrum users and generate valuable data for improving spectrum usage efficiency and guiding regulatory decisions. The necessary progression from scientific research to engineering prototypes and field trials is key to ensure trustworthy operations and compliance with spectrum regulations.  In preparation for future field experiments, potential sites should offer attributes that could contribute to the success of the experiment. Such attributes might include a site with a vast geographical footprint and low likelihood of radio frequency interference; an isolated site offering a lower risk to potential incumbents, making it ideal for experiments closely connected with specific operations, such as radio astronomy; and a site capable of integrating equipment into the spectrum monitoring capability and infrastructure to support simultaneous monitoring and experimental execution.

The project stressed the importance of engaging with the NRDZ community and stakeholders to guide field trial selection and implementation. Successful RDZ creation and operation was identified as essential, including spectrum monitoring, data analysis, and experiment scheduling. A strategic approach to field trials was discussed, including staged deployment and leveraging knowledge from initial trials for subsequent experiments.

Future research will set the vision for a National Radio Dynamic Zone and the National Experimental Facility for Spectrum Innovation to support interdisciplinary research and development of spectrum applications.  By improving spectrum access, this work will bolstered U.S. national security and economic competitiveness while accelerating scientific exploration.
